➤Modal auxiliaries are auxiliary verbs that lend different shades of meaning to the main verb to which they are attached. 

 ➤Modals help to express the mood or attitude of the speaker and convey ideas about possibility, probability, necessity, obligation, advisability, and permission.


 1. CAN 

 ➤Ability, doubt, astonishment, permission, Polite request 

 • I can play the football. 
 • Can I go out tonight?


 2.Could


 ➤Past time ability/inability, polite permission, polite order


 • I could not drive a four wheeler. 
 • Could I use your pen? 
 • Could you switch on the fan?


 3.Shall 

 ➤Used with ‘I’ and ‘WE’ for future tense, suggestion, willingness 

 • I shall meet you. 
 • Shall I go instead of you? 
 • Shall I bring a cup of coffee for you?


 4.Should 

 ➤To express one’s advice to others, necessity questions. 

 • You should improve your handwriting. 
 • Should I go in person? 

 5.Will 

 ➤To express determination, characteristic habit, invitation /a request, stronger possibility, to indicate uncertainty. 

 • Will you go to Chennai? 
 • She will sit with the novel for hours. 
 • Will you sing a song? 
 • That will be the milk maid. 
 • India will win the match. 

 6.Would 

 ➤Same as ‘will’, ask for opinion on something. 

 • I would go to Chennai every week. 
 • Would you mind coming tomorrow? 

 7.May 

 ➤ossibility/doubtfulness, express greetings/wishes, humble request. 

 • Ram may visit you. 
 • May God bless you. 
 • May I help you? 

 8. Might 

 ➤Remote possibility. 

 •The patient might recover. 
 •The medicine might cure you. 

 9. Must 

 ➤Compelling one to do or not do something. 

 • You must pay for your sin.


 *’have to’ can also be used in the place of ‘must’ 

 • You have to write the test.
